Let's talk about a few reasons why the Census is so important:

1) It determines how federal aid is distributed and ensures accurate representation for districts at both the state and federal level.

2) It helps all Georgia communities plan for the future.

3) It is a count of everyone who lives in the United States, including non-citizens. No questions about citizenship will appear on the questionnaire.

So. Now that we have established it's importance, let's talk about how you can fill it out...

A) online @ my2020census.gov OR

B) over the phone by calling 1-844-330-2020 OR

C) by filling out and returning the official U.S. Census Bureau mail you received.

It's that easy, and it's that important.

Georgia Census 2020 #EveryOneCounts #EveryoneCountsInBarrow

Barrow County Emergency Services recently began a new recruit class. This recruit class experienced a live burn in the burn building for the first time on Friday, August 7. We were there to take some pictures to let the general public get a taste of what the new recruits experience.

The training the recruits were doing in the building is called a Settee. There are 11 recruits in the class and as you can see in the pictures all eleven are in the building at the same time, along with three instructors. In this training exercise the recruits sit inside, feel the heat of the fire and learn to watch how the fire moves. The temperature of the fire in the building peaked at 999°. One instructor even had a boot to melt!

This exercise took place first thing Friday morning and lasted around 25 minutes. Later that day they had hostile environment training. Training is intense for these recruits so that they are ready to protect our citizens upon their completion and graduation of the 14 week course.

We wanted to take a moment to highlight the amazing work Barrow County Senior Center has been doing in our community. Since the pandemic started in March, the center has not missed a single day of hot meal delivery. In fact, the center is the only one, among 13 counties in the Northeast Georgia Area Agency on Aging chapter, that has not missed a weekday of serving in-person, daily meals to seniors during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Not only have they kept daily delivery, but they’ve also provided daily wellness checks and made phone calls twice a week to senior center members who opted out of meal delivery. In addition, the center has been sending out weekly newsletters and hosting trivia on Facebook Live to connect virtually with their senior members.

The Victor Lord Park expansion project in Barrow County is nearing completion and we couldn't be more excited!

Last week, ACCG Georgia Counties highlighted details about the park in their Local Lens newsletter. Check out the story below:

"Barrow County is celebrating the near completion of a $7.3 million park expansion at Victor Lord Park. Additions include a multipurpose synthetic turf field, two multipurpose grass sodded fields, a grandstand/scoring building, park amenities/restroom building, an eight tennis court/16 pickleball court center and a dog park. The park hosts year-round sporting events and has over 100,000 visitors annually."

Traffic shift on West Winder Bypass project this week

Winder, Ga., - On Wednesday traffic will shift over to the newly constructed northbound lanes on Patrick Mill Road.

Construction partners will begin moving barrels early that morning and traffic should be using the new lanes by 9 a.m.

Please slow down while traveling through the work zone as traffic will be adjusting to a new alignment.

The west winder bypass project proposes to realign SR 211 over SR 8 and the railroad in Winder onto the existing Patrick Mill Road. The construction process will occur in three phases.

This project was awarded to E.R. Snell Contractor, Inc. in August 2018 for approximately $59 million.

We would like to remind everyone that although we are currently in a “State of Emergency” it is not a reason to panic. Declaring the COVID-19 a national emergency allowed the federal government to free up nearly $50 billion in disaster money to fight the spread of the virus. It will also allow for expanded capacity at hospitals and reduce other health regulations that could slow action. The president has also declared an emergency under the National Emergencies Act, which will allow for Department of Health and Human Services to modify or waive regulations for Medicare, Medicaid and other programs.

The Stafford Act was created in 1988 to allow the federal government to offer a wide range of aid to states, municipalities, hospitals and even individuals. These declarations of emergency are POSITIVE THINGS from a public health standpoint. Let’s all stay calm and work together throughout this event.

shared_text:
Barrow County Public Works
January 28 at 12:28 PM ·

Public Advisory
BOIL WATER NOTICE
The isolation of a large diameter water main for repair is causing water pressure in parts of the water system to drop to dangerously low levels. In order to protect the public from a potential health hazard, all citizens that have experienced water outages and/or low water pressures are advised to “boil” all water prior to use for drinking, cooking, or preparing baby food. The water should be boiled for at least one minute after reaching a rolling boil. Citizens should continue to boil their water until they are notified by the Barrow County Water Department that the water system has been restored to full operation, and that the microbiological quality of the water in the distribution system is safe for human consumption. This notice will be updated in 24 hours.
Known areas affected:
Emerald Pointe Subdivision
If you should have any questions, please contact the Barrow County Water Department at 770-307-3014.

Members of the Farmers Market Board are:

Alicia Holloway - Barrow County Extension Office
John Huff - Wimberly's Roots
Ty Brooks - Wimberly's Roots
Danielle Austin - Barrow County Board of Commissioners
Staci Waters - Barrow County Farm Bureau
Rachel Winkel - R & K Real Food Farm
Tiffany Coles - Barrow County 4-H

Vendor applications will be available in January and the first market will take place April 18, 2020. Time to get excited, Barrow County!

November 11, 2019 at 3:05 PM ·

Public Advisory
BOIL WATER NOTICE

The isolation of a large diameter water main for repair is causing water pressure in parts of the water system to drop to dangerously low levels. In order to protect the public from a potential health hazard, all citizens that have experienced water outages and/or low water pressures are advised to “boil” all water prior to use for drinking, cooking, or preparing baby food. The water should be boiled for at least one minute after reaching a rolling boil. Citizens should continue to boil their water until they are notified by the Barrow County Water Dept. that the water system has been restored to full operation, and that the microbiological quality of the water in the distribution system is safe for human consumption. This notice will be updated in 24 hours.
Known areas affected:
Bowman Mill Road from Pleasant Hill Church Road to Hwy 211 NE
Royal Oaks Subdivision
Anchor Heights Subdivision
